title: Hsp60 protein pattern in coral is altered by environmental changes in light and temperature
abstract: The heat shock protein Hsp60 exhibited marked oscillation during a 12-hour day period when the coral Turbinaria reniformis was maintained in the laboratory under constant conditions of light (200 μE) and temperature (27°C). A biphasic pattern of Hsp60 was apparent, punctuated by a low protein level at the midpoint of the 12-hour day period. Oscillation of Hsp60 was also apparent when coral was kept in darkness in lieu of a scheduled light period. The pattern of Hsp60 was altered when coral was exposed to increased light intensity (400 μE) or temperature elevation (32°C). These observations suggest that Hsp60 in coral exhibits oscillation that is altered by increased light and temperature elevation.

abstract.text: The heat shock protein Hsp60 exhibited marked oscillation during a 12-hour day period when the coral Turbinaria reniformis was maintained in the laboratory under constant conditions of light (200 μE) and temperature (27°C). A biphasic pattern of Hsp60 was apparent, punctuated by a low protein level at the midpoint of the 12-hour day period. Oscillation of Hsp60 was also apparent when coral was kept in darkness in lieu of a scheduled light period. The pattern of Hsp60 was altered when coral was exposed to increased light intensity (400 μE) or temperature elevation (32°C). These observations suggest that Hsp60 in coral exhibits oscillation that is altered by increased light and temperature elevation.

body_text.text: Coral reefs are one of the most diverse and valuable marine ecosystems (Costanza et al., 1997) . It is important to increase our understanding of the interaction between corals and their environment as these fragile communities are threatened by events associated with global warming. Temperature elevation due to El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) is a major contributor to coral bleaching which is the loss of photosynthetic capacity (Brown, 1997; Stone et al., 1999) . Light intensity is known to affect the health of coral beds, inducing bleaching (Lesser and Farrell, 2004; Abrego et al., 2008) . A range of other environmental factors also cause stress in coral such as salinity changes, cold stress, bacterial infections, sedimentation, pesticides and pollution (Muscatine et al., 1991; Banin et al., 2000; Brown, 2000; Markey et al., 2007; Downs et al., 2009) .

In response to environmental perturbation, organisms induce stress proteins, also known as heat shock proteins (Hsps), that play essential roles in cellular repair and protective mechanisms (Arya et al., 2007; Lanneau et al., 2010; Richter et al., 2010) . Studies on coral have focused primarily on Hsp70 and Hsp90, including examination of transcript expression by microarray analysis (Hayes and King, 1995; Sharp et al., 1997; Tom et al., 1999; Carpenter et al., 2010; Levy et al., 2011; Rosic et al., 2011 ). In the current study, we examine Hsp60 protein levels in the coral Turbinaria reniformis during the time course of a 12-hour day period, and the effect of temperature elevation and increased light intensity. Hsp60 plays important roles in mitochondrial biogenesis (Voos and Rottgers, 2002) . It is involved in protein import into mitochondria that is crucial for mitochondrial function (Hood et al., 2003) . Hsp60 has anti-apoptotic ability and can protect against cell death by maintaining mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (Kirchhoff et al., 2002; Veereshwarayya et al., 2006; Arya et al., 2007) . Our present observations indicate that Hsp60 exhibits marked oscillation when light and temperature conditions remain constant. This oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 is altered when coral is exposed to changes in environmental conditions involving elevation of temperature and light intensity.

T. reniformis is a scleractinian coral that is widespread in coral reefs (Veron, 2000) . The International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources lists T. reniformis as a threatened species that is susceptible to bleaching due to its restricted depth range. Declines in habitat quality have been reported for its range (Wilkinson, 2004) . T. reniformis is an experimental model system that can be cultured under controlled laboratory conditions, and it has been employed for our investigation of the effect of light and feeding on coral metabolism (Treignier et al., 2008; Treignier et al., 2009; Tolosa et al., 2011) .
The coral T. reniformis, collected from the Red Sea, were maintained under laboratory culture conditions since 2008 (Treignier et al., 2008) .

Nubbins (69 coral tips) were cultured for three weeks prior to experimentation. Salinity and pH of sea water in aquarium tanks were kept constant (Ferrier-Pagès et al., 1999; Godinot et al., 2011) . Normal water temperature was set at 27°C (precision: ±0.1°C), logged at 10 min intervals using a Seamon temperature recorder. Halide lamps (400 W, Philips, HPIT) provided a PAR irradiance (Ferrier-Pagès et al., 2007) of 200±20 μmol photons m − 2 s − 1 (μE), (photoperiod 12:12 h), measured using a 4π quantum sensor . The halide lamps were turned on at 9:00 h for the day cycle and turned off at 21:00 h.

Nubbins were subjected to the following conditions: (a) constant light and water temperature conditions (200 μE, 27°C) as specified in Section 2.1 for normal growth conditions, (b) increased light intensity (400 μE, 27°C), (c) temperature elevation (200 μE, 32°C), (d) dark condition (lights turned off in lieu of a scheduled 12-hour day period, 27°C), and (e) temperature elevation in dark (lights turned off in lieu of a scheduled 12-hour day period, 32°C). Nubbins were collected at the intervals indicated in the figures, frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80°C. For the light withdrawal experiment, nubbins were harvested in the first day cycle without light after 0, 3, 6 and 12 h of additional darkness following a regularly scheduled dark period. Three independent experimental repeats were carried out. Treatment conditions b) to e) [namely increased light intensity, temperature elevation, light withdrawal, and light withdrawal plus temperature elevation] commenced at the zero time point shown in Figs. 1 to 3 and nubbins were harvested at the times indicated in these figures, that is 0 to 12 h.
body_text.section: Increased light intensity and temperature elevation

body_text.text: Nubbins were harvested and processed by grinding under liquid nitrogen, weighed, and proteins extracted in 20 μL g − 1 of cold buffer containing: 500 mM potassium phosphate (pH: 7.8), 10% L-ascorbic acid, 20 mM phenyl methyl sulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), and 10 mg mL − 1 protease inhibitor cocktail. Skeleton fragments were removed by centrifugation on a nylon mesh (1000 g, 10 min, 4°C) and extracted proteins were freeze-dried.

Samples were solubilized in Laemmli buffer and boiled for min, before centrifugation for 15 s at 16,000 g to remove insoluble particles. Lowry assay was performed for protein concentration quantification (Peterson, 1977) . Equal loadings of 50 μg of protein per lane were separated by 12% SDS-PAGE using the Mini-PROTEAN 3 Electrophoresis Module Assembly (Bio-Rad) with a stacking gel of 4%, using the standard buffer system of Laemmli, before transferring to nitrocellulose membranes. Antibody specific for Hsp60 (SPA-807) was obtained from StressGen Biotechnologies (British Columbia, Canada). Western blots representative of three experimental repeats are shown. Results were substantiated using a second Hsp60 antibody (SPA-805, Stress-Gen). Optical density representations of bands were determined by Alpha Innotech FluorChem imaging software. Equal protein loading in all lanes of the Western blots was confirmed by Ponceau S staining (Figure S1 Supplementary Material).

Data were expressed as the mean ± standard error of the means (SEM). One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey's HSD post hoc tests for pair-wise comparison of means was used to assess significant differences (p b 0.05) in Hsp60 protein levels during constant light and temperature conditions and in response to increased light intensity and temperature elevation. Two-way ANOVA was used to assess if the pattern altering effect of various treatments on Hsp60 levels was significant (p b 0.05).

The coral T. reniformis was maintained under laboratory culture conditions. As shown in Fig. 1 , the heat shock protein Hsp60 exhibited marked oscillation during the course of a 12-hour day period and a biphasic pattern was observed. Two peaks of Hsp60 were apparent at the 2 and 10 h time points, punctuated by a low level at the midpoint of the 12-hour day period. One-way ANOVA revealed that the biphasic pattern of Hsp60 was significant, F(6,14) = 9.562, p = 0.0003.
body_text.section: Oscillation of coral Hsp60 during constant light and temperature conditions

body_text.text: The biphasic pattern of Hsp60 during the 12-hour day period was altered when normal light intensity (200 μE) was increased to 400 μE. As shown in Fig. 2A , Hsp60 was initially suppressed at 3 h followed by a marked elevation at 6 and 12 h, whereas at normal light intensity, low levels of Hsp60 were apparent at 6 and 12 h. Two-way ANOVA revealed that the effect of increased light intensity was significantly different from that of normal light, F(1, 16) = 11.99, p = 0.003.
body_text.section: Effect of increased light intensity on Hsp60

body_text.text: Temperature elevation also disrupted the oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 (Fig. 2B ). Water temperature was increased from 27°C to 32°C, while maintaining normal light intensity (200 μE). Hsp60 was not reduced at 6 h as was noted for the biphasic pattern observed at 27°C. Two-way ANOVA revealed that the effect of temperature elevation was significantly different from that of normal temperature, F(1, 16) = 14.25, p =0.002.
body_text.section: Temperature elevation in the presence of normal light

body_text.text: A light withdrawal experiment was performed by keeping coral in darkness in lieu of a scheduled 12-hour day period. As shown in Fig. 3A , an oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 was observed, punctuated by a low point at 6 h. Two-way ANOVA revealed that the effect of light withdrawal was significantly different from that of normal light, F(1, 16) = 59.66, p b 0.0001.
body_text.section: Effect of light withdrawal on Hsp60

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. 3B , the oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 observed under dark conditions was disrupted when coral was exposed to temperature elevation in darkness. Two-way ANOVA revealed that the effect of temperature elevation in darkness was significantly different from that of light withdrawal alone, F(1, 16) = 6.67, P = 0.02.

Our present results indicate that Hsp60 protein exhibits marked oscillation during the course of a 12-hour day period under conditions when light intensity and temperature remain constant. A biphasic pattern of Hsp60 was apparent, punctuated by a low level at the midpoint of the 12-hour day period. An oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 was also observed when coral was kept in darkness in lieu of a scheduled light period. This suggests that Hsp60 protein levels may be related to, or governed by, an oscillatory mechanism. Interestingly, the oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 is altered by increased light intensity and temperature elevation. The observed changes in Hsp60 could reflect changes in protein degradation and/or release of Hsp60 into the environment.

In situ measurements on corals in their natural environments demonstrate cycles of photosynthesis (Kaniewska et al., 2009; Schneider et al., 2009) . However, due to the presence of fluctuations in light intensity and temperature in natural coral reef habitats, distinctions cannot be made between molecular components that cycle as a response to environmental cues and those molecules that might serves as oscillators. A report on photosynthesis in corals cultured under controlled conditions suggests that this process is lightdependent rather than following an endogenous cycle (Moya et al., 2006) . Our studies indicate that Hsp60 exhibits oscillation when light and temperature conditions remain constant.

Our results demonstrate that the oscillatory pattern of Hsp60 is altered by increased light intensity and temperature elevation. It is noteworthy that environmental signals have been reported to affect biological cycles in several systems. Light influences the entrainment of biological rhythm in many species including plants, insects and mammals (reviewed by Cashmore, 2003) . In the reef-building coral Acropora millepora, light affects the expression of the cryptochrome genes cry1 and cry2 that act as photoreceptors for blue light that entrains coral cycles (Levy et al., 2007) . Temperature is an important environmental factor that influences oscillators in many organisms, acting as a resetting cue (reviewed by Ruoff and Rensing, 2004) . A link with metabolic status has recently been established as feeding influences biological cycles in plants, mammals and cyanobacteria (reviewed by Bass and Takahashi, 2010; Bellet and Sassone-Corsi, 2010) .

When excess light is absorbed by photosynthetic organisms, photo-oxidative damage may lead to photoinhibition (Li et al., 2009) . Biphasic daily variation of photosynthetic capacity has been reported in coral with maximum photosynthetic efficiency occurring in the morning and in the afternoon (Chalker and Taylor, 1978) . This correlates with the biphasic peaks of Hsp60 observed in the present study. Interestingly, Hsp60 has been linked to the photosynthetic apparatus in a report demonstrating that Hsp60 associates with Rubisco activase, potentially preventing its thermally induced unfolding (Salvucci, 2008) . We have previously suggested that Hsp60 in coral may have enhanced protein folding ability to cater for changes in environmental conditions (Chow et al., 2009) . Rubisco activase is heat sensitive, the limiting factor of photosynthesis at high temperature, and maintains Rubisco in a catalytically active form to permit carbon fixation (Portis, 1995; Salvucci and Ogren, 1996 ; Crafts-Brandner and Salvucci, 2000) . Interruption of carbon fixation by expression of mutant Rubisco inhibits the photosynthetic apparatus at the level of the photosystem II (PSII) repair process Murata, 2005, 2006) .

Hsp60 plays a critical role in protein import into mitochondria that is crucial for mitochondrial function (Hood et al., 2003) . Mutations of hsp60 induce respiratory defects in yeast (Sanyal et al., 1995) . Functional respiratory machinery is required for active photosynthesis (Kromer, 1995; Dutilleul et al., 2003; Raghavendra and Padmasree, 2003) . In coral, rates of photosynthesis and respiration increase in parallel in response to light (Mass et al., 2010) . As a result, oscillation of Hsp60 is potentially beneficial for increased respiratory demand during cycles of photosynthesis.

Although temperature is well established as one of the important cues that entrain biological cycles (Liu et al., 1998; Rensing and Ruoff, 2002; Glaser and Stanewsky, 2005; Lahiri et al., 2005; Yoshida et al., 2009; Buhr et al., 2010) , the correlation of heat shock protein (Hsps) to biological cycles has received comparatively little attention. Interestingly, examination of global gene expression in the plant Arabidopsis has revealed cyclical expression of hsp60 mRNA (Rasmusson and Escobar, 2007) . Other members of the Hsp gene family, namely hsp70 and hsp90, display cycles of gene expression in the coral Acropora millepora as examined by microarray analysis (Levy et al., 2011) . Hsps transcripts including hspa1b (encoding Hsp70), hspca (encoding Hsp90), and hsp105 (encoding Hsp105) show cyclical expression in phase with the clock gene per2 in mouse liver (Kornmann et al., 2007) . Disruption of the synthesis of heat shock proteins by the inhibitor KNK437 influences the expression of the clock gene per2 in mouse pituitary and lung cultures (Buhr et al., 2010) . Loss of Hsp90 function disrupts behavioral variation in Drosophila (Hung et al., 2009) . In addition, a heat shock transcription factor demonstrates oscillatory DNA-binding activity in a screen using differential display of DNAbinding proteins (Reinke et al., 2008) . Hence increasing evidence links genes encoding heat shock proteins to biological cycles.
A.M. Chow et al. / Comparative Biochemistry and Physiology, Part A 161 (2012) 349-353

back_matter.text: We thank Hashwin V.S. Ganesh for technical assistance with preparation of the samples for Western blot analysis. This study was supported by grants from i) NSERC Canada to I.R.B who also holds a Canada Research Chair (Tier I) and ii) the Centre Scientifique de Monaco to C.F.-P.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at doi:10. 1016/j.cbpa.2011.12.004.

Nonparametric en- trainment of the in vitro circadian phosphorylation rhythm of cyanobacterial KaiC by temperature cycle. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 106, 1648-1653.

FIGREF0.text: Variation of heat shock protein Hsp60 levels in the coral T. reniformis cultured under constant light and temperature conditions. Immunoblotting demonstrated a pronounced biphasic pattern of Hsp60 over the course of a 12-hour day period. Equal protein loading in each lane was confirmed by Ponceau S staining of Western blots in Figs. 1 to 3 (SeeFig. S1 Supplementary Material). Data are expressed as mean ± SEM. Different symbols on columns of the bar graph indicate significant differences (oneway ANOVA followed by Tukey's HSD multiple pair-wise comparisons): Δ pb 0.05 compared to 2 h; # pb 0.05 compared to 10 h.

FIGREF1.text: Effect of increased light intensity and temperature elevation on Hsp60. (A) Increased light intensity (400 μE) at normal temperature (27°C). (B) Temperature elevation (32°C) at normal light intensity (200 μE). Data are expressed as mean ± SEM (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's HSD multiple pair-wise comparisons, *p b 0.05 compared to 0 h).

FIGREF2.text: Effect of light withdrawal on Hsp60. (A) Coral was kept in darkness in lieu of a scheduled light period. (B) Temperature elevation to 32°C in darkness. Data are expressed as mean ±SEM (one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's HSD multiple pair-wise comparisons, *p b 0.05 compared to 0 h).

FIGREF3.text: Tukey post hoc comparisons revealed that Hsp60 protein level is significantly increased at 2 h (4 h: MD = 1.174, p b 0.001; 6 h: MD = 1.175, p b 0.001; 8 h: MD = 0.7155, p b 0.05; 12 h: MD = 1.025, p b 0.01) and at 10 h (4 h: MD = 0.6895, p b 0.05; 6 h: MD = 0.6912, p b 0.05). These novel results reveal the oscillatory nature of Hsp60 when light (200 μE) and temperature (27°C) conditions remained constant. The effect of increased light intensity and temperature elevation on this pattern of Hsp60 was next examined.
